intro: Pimpinella huillensis var. elatior, commonly known as the Huillén mountain parsley, is a rare and endemic species native to the high Andes of South America. It is characterized by its finely divided, feathery leaves and small, yellowish-white flowers that bloom in early spring. The plant typically grows in rocky, well-drained soils at high altitudes, often in alpine or subalpine environments. Its botanical structure reflects adaptations to cold and harsh climatic conditions, with a compact growth habit and a short growing season. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a species of conservation concern.
